data.label:
Narrator

It was raining as Serge dropped me off at home after yet another gruelling day of work.

Narrator

I flipped on the light in the kitchen to find a note from Monica.

Narrator

While it was heating up, I went to the living room to fix myself a drink.

Player

"Your mother works harder than I do these days."

Franc

"Oh, right. My commander's worried women might be allowed into the military now. He thinks they're too emotional to serve."

Player

"She's off on her ladies' crusade, as usual."

Player

"Hello to you too, Franc."

Franc

"I didn't mean it that way! I just figured you'd be working."

Franc

"Have you heard anything from Uncle Petr?"

Player

"That's still too painful to talk about."

Player

"You take that back."

Player

"Glad you liked it."

Player

"Petr thought you might like it."

Franc

"Wow. Did I just see a pig fly?"

Franc

"Some of the profs here were hoping you'd hire a new VP who'd push you closer to Malenyevism."

Franc

"Uh, okay. It's so messed up what he did."

Player

"I'll see what I can do to alleviate tensions. The last thing I want is my son going into battle."

Player

"Ha! Never."

Franc

"I know, Dad. I'm ready to fight if I have to."

Franc

"I'm ready to fight if I have to."

Franc

"Even if that means sacrificing your only son. Got it."

Player

"So, got a girlfriend yet?"

Player

"So, made any new friends yet?"

Player

"So, made any new friends yet?"

Franc

"I have, actually. But some of the older guys are getting transferred up by Mougwer. In case things escalate with Rumburg."

Player

"Absence makes the heart grow fonder."

Player

"That's my boy."

Franc

"It's all right. They keep talking about how things might escalate with Rumburg."

Rumburg Army Talk

Rumburg Army Talk

Franc

"Not that it's any of your business, but I might be seeing someone. She's no fan of yours, though. You know... With all the protests here."

Franc

"It's still mostly just the same guys from high school. I have to say, they're no fans of yours these days. A lot of student protests are happening here, you know..."

Franc

"It's fine, in between all the demonstrations."

Player

"Nothing a bit of tear gas can't fix."

Player

"Well, I hope you're putting in a good word for me."

Player

"Are you joining the revolution, son?"

Player

"Have the freedom lunatics gotten to your head already?"

Franc

"But I guess you don't feel the same way, since you made that deal with Valgsland."

Player

"That had nothing to do with my personal politics. It was simply the most convenient option."

Player

"You never paid attention to my politics back at home."

Player

"I sent you over there to get a quality education, not fill your head with Arcasian propaganda."

Player

"You never paid attention to my politics back at home."

Franc

"Well, it was the wrong move. Aligning with us is the only way forward."

Franc

"Well, it was the right move. Aligning with us is the only way forward."

Franc

"I mean, they're obviously doing something right."

Franc

"You must think so too, or you wouldn't have made that deal with Valgsland."

Player

"I sent you over there to get a free education, not fill your head with Contanan propaganda."

Player

"Franc. I'd never put you on the front lines."

Franc

"If it came to it? I'd blow my own brains out before I died for you."

Franc

"I'm graduating from basic training soon. The commander says I could be the next Iosef Lancea."

Franc

"Actually, Dad..."

Player

"What?! You'll make me look like an idiot!"

Player

"Good for you. Exercise your right to freedom of speech."

Player

"What?! You could get hurt!"

Franc

"You-- you're not mad at me?"

Player

"No. I was a student once too, you know."

Player

"No. Just disappointed you wouldn't talk to me beforehand."

Franc

"Not everyone can get a personal audience with the President of Sordland, Dad. It sends a more powerful message if I'm there with my fellow citizens."

Player

"Well, message received."

Franc

"Too chicken to do it yourself? Typical."

Player

"You were born with privilege. Take advantage of it."

Franc

"My head's been stuffed with Sordish propaganda since the day I was born. Right now I feel like I'm thinking clearly for the first time."

Franc

"But I'm aware that you disagree."

Franc

"Oh, I am."

Player

"It's 'us' now?"

Player

"I think you're forgetting where you came from..."

Player

"If you like it over there so much, don't bother ever coming home."

Player

"Don't come crying to me if you get shot by some Arcasian gun nut."

Player

"I'm happy you're opening your mind. Just stay away from reefer."

Narrator

I suddenly became aware of a smoky smell coming from the kitchen. My dinner was burning.

Player_Italic

I hung up the phone without saying goodbye to Franc.

Player

"I have to go. Try calling your mother tomorrow."

Narrator

I brought the pizza into the living room and opened two beers. Serge and I sat down and ate together by the flickering light of the television.

Narrator

I raced to the stove and turned off the burner. The bottom of the pot was charred, but part of the mystery stew was still salvageable.

Franc

"Maybe I won't!"

Player

"Not until you put on a few hundred pounds."

Franc

"I'll try."

Franc

"Honestly, I was so ticked off at you for sending me here, but I'm really starting to like it. Thank God for failure, right?"

Franc

"Ooh, don't say that if you ever visit. Assuming you want to leave with your legs intact."

Player

"Watch your mouth, or I'll personally transfer you to the border myself."

Player

"Luckily, there are thousands of Sordish troops who don't think the same way."

Player

"Are you kidding me? You WILL stop it from now on!"

Franc

"Not if you call off your dogs. Police violence in this country has gone too far."

Franc

"And not if you stop detaining people without just cause."

Franc

"The way things are going now, you don't need my help to look like an idiot."

Franc

"You can't make me. This is still a democracy, right?"

Franc

"See, that's the sort of attitude we're protesting against."

Player

"You want a powerful message? How about I send Karl to beat the shit out of every last one of you?"

Franc

"Just think about what we have to say. That's all I ask."

Player

"I did my share of marching and placard-waving. Didn't get us anywhere, but it felt good."

Franc

"It's still mostly just the same guys from high school. Although there's this girl I've been seeing sometimes."

Franc

"Are you sure you'd want to? She's Bludish."

Franc

"She's beautiful."

Player

"I'm surprised she'd be interested in the president's son, then."

Player

"I'm sure she's a lovely girl. But her people still pose a danger to us."

Player

"She's got you henpecked already, I see."

Player

"I'll make sure her family is protected."

Franc

"You really don't get it, do you?"

Franc

"She's amazing. Bludish, actually. Her parents are big supporters of yours."

Franc

"She's gorgeous. Bludish, actually. Her parents are big supporters of yours."

Franc

"Probably soon, if she gets her way. She's Bludish, actually. Her parents are big supporters of yours."

Franc

"Maybe I'll bring her for dinner next week."

Player

"I like her already."

Franc

"So, uh, I've been seeing this new girl at school."

Franc

"I'm graduating from basic training soon. The commander says I could be the next Iosef Lancea."

Player

"Not until you put on a few hundred pounds."

Player

"Sorry, you can't. You've got too much hair."

Franc

"Ooh, don't say that if you ever visit. Assuming you want to leave with your legs intact."

Franc

"I'll try."

Narrator

Franc stifled a laugh.

Franc

"A few, yeah."

Player

"Do you even know what he did?"

Player

"The cabinet chooses the candidates, Franc. I didn't have many choices."

Player

"Be careful, Franc. These protests are getting dangerous."

Franc

"Emergency? Uh, that's the point."

Player

"Something can happen to you, son. And I may not be able to help you."

Player

"Don't be a smartass, Franc."

Player

"Just be careful. Alright?"

Player

"So, how do you find the land of capitalism?"

Player

"So, how do you find the land of socialism?"

Player

"You're going too far, Franc."

Player

"Just be careful, Franc. I don't want you to get brainwashed there."

Player

"Serge, would you like to join me for dinner? There's an FC Anrica game today."

Serge Wolkner

"It would be an honor to watch your team together, sir. "

Player

"Bludish? Maybe you should stop seeing her."

Player

"I'm doing my best, son. But the militants there are making it hard for us."

Narrator

It was raining as Serge dropped me off at home after yet another gruelling day of work.

Narrator

It was raining as Serge dropped me off at home after yet another gruelling day of work.

Narrator

It was raining as Serge dropped me off at home after yet another gruelling day of work.

Narrator

It was raining as Serge dropped me off at home after yet another gruelling day of work.

Narrator

I flipped on the light in the kitchen to find a note from Monica.

Player

"It's dinnertime for me."

Player

"Bye, son."

Player

"Talk to you soon."

Player

"See you for dinner soon."

Player

"Stay safe over there."

Player

"You were never a failure."

Player

"I'm glad you came to see it my way."

Serge Wolkner

"I'd love to, sir. But I promised Suzan I would watch the children tonight."
